Three periods of competition for candidates for the News-Letter
Yonkers,
New York.
are provided in its constitution. The spring competition starts with
this issue and ends May 25. An opportunity is here offered candidates
to be selected to the staff before the close of the year. Candidates
are requested to report for assignments at the News-Letter office on
Tuesdays and Fridays.

The Johns Hopkins News-Letter

Payne &Merrill

S

STETSON HATS
Styled for young men

APPRECIATION!
With this issue the 1924-25 Board assumes control of the NewsLetter. It takes up its tasks with a feeling of appreciation of the
untiring efforts and perseverance of the outgoing staff. Under
the
guidance of its members the paper has prospered and has been
led
through a banner year.
During the administration of the old editors many important
changes have taken place on the Hopkins campus. Our "Fairy
Godmother" has been unusually kind to us by erecting a dormitory
and
a new chemical laboratory. Athletic and non-athletic activities
have
shown improvement under efficient management. Our teams—foot
ball, lacrosse, swimming, track--have become famous and bear enviable reputations. Two possible candidates for the Olympic
Games
have been developed. The Barnstormers have been ushered in and
have paved the way for a probable all-Hopkins production. The
prestige of the Musical Club has increased.- On the whole campus
activities have progressed and have been constantly brought
before
the public eye. Many campus changes can be attributed directly
or
indirectly to suggestions and criticisms from the editorial column
of the News-Letter.
We, the incoming board, are attempting to carry on the work
started by our predecessors. Our aim is to give a "newsier"
and
better paper. We endeavor to reflect, impartially, as best we
can,
the correct undergraduate sentiment. If criticism and
discussion
result, we accomplish our purpose to stimulate thought.
The News-Letter is proud of its twenty-seven years of
service.
It is more interested, however, in the years of the future. It is
with
this interest and a sincere hope for progress that the new board
of
editors assumes its duties.

DEBATE ANNOUNCED BETWEEN HOPKINS AND U.
OF RICHMOND
A debate on March 25 between
Hopkins and the University of
Richmond was recently announced

by the Debating Council. The following subject has been chosen:
"Resolved, That the United States
should enter the World Court."
The Hopkins debaters will take
the affirmative side of the argument.

The Hopkins team will consist
of
William Gross, Owens Rea and
BIDDERS
PRMTERS
EllgRAVERS
Elmer Mylander, alternate. The
visitors have not yet announced
their team.
Collele Literature
The choice of a Tuesday night
for the debate will mark an innovation in Hopkins debating. The
reason given for this action is the
drive on the part of the Debating
Council to get larger audiences at
the debates. It is felt that a larger
attendance can be expected on
evenings when there is no other
important social event in progress.
As an added attraction, an informal dance will immediately follow
the debate, which will be held in
the C. E. Hall.

In this season of try-outs, seniors will do well
to respond to the call for candidates which progressive business organizations are making.
The visit of the various company representatives
offers a mutual opportunity. It puts you in position to judge whether a particular company offers
sufficient scope to your ability and ambition.
The representative can judge, after conversing
with you and studying your record, whether you
would be well placed in his company.
Do not ignore the invitation to these interviews.
Do not be one of those—and they are many—
who next Fall will write to the larger companies,
"At the time your representative visited my
college I did not think that I was interested in the
work of your company and so did not meet him".
Men who are earnest in wanting to make the
team usually respond to first call

FURNITURE

SENIOR CLASS MEETING
Details for the Senior banquet
are still hazily indefinite, but one
point has been decided: the banquet is to be a credit to the class,
not a disgrace. This decision,
reached in a Senior Class meeting,
last Tuesday, does not, according
to its exponents, mean that the affair will be 'bone dry," but it does
imply "safe and sane" conditions
will prevail for the most part. The
committee, headed by John Shriver, is now making actual arrangements for the banquet.
At the close of the discussion of
the banquet, June Week plans
were outlined. A committee of
Seniors is to arrange for the electrical illumination of the campus.
Step-singing also was discussed
and suitable selections are now
being sought for the occasion.

Camaraderie
will be the keynote of this exceptional voyage,the entire 3rd
class accommodations of the Cunarder "Saxonia" having
been reserved exclusively for college men. Men from every
corner of the country are availing themselves of the low tariff, special service
and restricted reservation to satisfy their
heart's desire to travel. Climb on the
band wagon! It will be the most glorious
summer you will ever know. Apply at
nearest Cunard Office, or write —
COLLEGE CABIN COMMITTEE

Three periods of competition for candidates for the News-Letter
Yonkers,
New York.
are provided in its constitution. The spring competition starts with
this issue and ends May 25. An opportunity is here offered candidates
to be selected to the staff before the close of the year. Candidates
are requested to report for assignments at the News-Letter office on
Tuesdays and Fridays.

The Johns Hopkins News-Letter

Payne &Merrill

S

STETSON HATS
Styled for young men

APPRECIATION!
With this issue the 1924-25 Board assumes control of the NewsLetter. It takes up its tasks with a feeling of appreciation of the
untiring efforts and perseverance of the outgoing staff. Under
the
guidance of its members the paper has prospered and has been
led
through a banner year.
During the administration of the old editors many important
changes have taken place on the Hopkins campus. Our "Fairy
Godmother" has been unusually kind to us by erecting a dormitory
and
a new chemical laboratory. Athletic and non-athletic activities
have
shown improvement under efficient management. Our teams—foot
ball, lacrosse, swimming, track--have become famous and bear enviable reputations. Two possible candidates for the Olympic
Games
have been developed. The Barnstormers have been ushered in and
have paved the way for a probable all-Hopkins production. The
prestige of the Musical Club has increased.- On the whole campus
activities have progressed and have been constantly brought
before
the public eye. Many campus changes can be attributed directly
or
indirectly to suggestions and criticisms from the editorial column
of the News-Letter.
We, the incoming board, are attempting to carry on the work
started by our predecessors. Our aim is to give a "newsier"
and
better paper. We endeavor to reflect, impartially, as best we
can,
the correct undergraduate sentiment. If criticism and
discussion
result, we accomplish our purpose to stimulate thought.
The News-Letter is proud of its twenty-seven years of
service.
It is more interested, however, in the years of the future. It is
with
this interest and a sincere hope for progress that the new board
of
editors assumes its duties.

DEBATE ANNOUNCED BETWEEN HOPKINS AND U.
OF RICHMOND
A debate on March 25 between
Hopkins and the University of
Richmond was recently announced

by the Debating Council. The following subject has been chosen:
"Resolved, That the United States
should enter the World Court."
The Hopkins debaters will take
the affirmative side of the argument.

The Hopkins team will consist
of
William Gross, Owens Rea and
BIDDERS
PRMTERS
EllgRAVERS
Elmer Mylander, alternate. The
visitors have not yet announced
their team.
Collele Literature
The choice of a Tuesday night
for the debate will mark an innovation in Hopkins debating. The
reason given for this action is the
drive on the part of the Debating
Council to get larger audiences at
the debates. It is felt that a larger
attendance can be expected on
evenings when there is no other
important social event in progress.
As an added attraction, an informal dance will immediately follow
the debate, which will be held in
the C. E. Hall.

In this season of try-outs, seniors will do well
to respond to the call for candidates which progressive business organizations are making.
The visit of the various company representatives
offers a mutual opportunity. It puts you in position to judge whether a particular company offers
sufficient scope to your ability and ambition.
The representative can judge, after conversing
with you and studying your record, whether you
would be well placed in his company.
Do not ignore the invitation to these interviews.
Do not be one of those—and they are many—
who next Fall will write to the larger companies,
"At the time your representative visited my
college I did not think that I was interested in the
work of your company and so did not meet him".
Men who are earnest in wanting to make the
team usually respond to first call

FURNITURE

SENIOR CLASS MEETING
Details for the Senior banquet
are still hazily indefinite, but one
point has been decided: the banquet is to be a credit to the class,
not a disgrace. This decision,
reached in a Senior Class meeting,
last Tuesday, does not, according
to its exponents, mean that the affair will be 'bone dry," but it does
imply "safe and sane" conditions
will prevail for the most part. The
committee, headed by John Shriver, is now making actual arrangements for the banquet.
At the close of the discussion of
the banquet, June Week plans
were outlined. A committee of
Seniors is to arrange for the electrical illumination of the campus.
Step-singing also was discussed
and suitable selections are now
being sought for the occasion.

JUNE 21

Camaraderie
will be the keynote of this exceptional voyage,the entire 3rd
class accommodations of the Cunarder "Saxonia" having
been reserved exclusively for college men. Men from every
corner of the country are availing themselves of the low tariff, special service
and restricted reservation to satisfy their
heart's desire to travel. Climb on the
band wagon! It will be the most glorious
summer you will ever know. Apply at
nearest Cunard Office, or write —
COLLEGE CABIN COMMITTEE
B. D. ADAMS, Chairman
